Idiom (Iban): Anang nyabak ke ai enti enda tau nyelam
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Negative imperative clause with conditional subordinate clause
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Do not criticize or judge what you don’t understand.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Don’t talk about things you don’t know.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Draws on Iban riverine life, where one must dive to understand the depth of water.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Iban): [ʔanaŋ ɲabak kə ai enti ʔənda taw ɲəlɐm]
First Example Sentence: Aku udah madah ka iya, anang nyabak ke ai enti enda tau nyelam, laban iya nadai pernah ngalami.
Second Example Sentence: Orang ke enda arap mesti diajar, anang nyabak ke ai enti enda tau nyelam.
Third Example Sentence: Enda patut kitai ngempu penemu enti enda nyelamka diri empu—anang nyabak ke ai enti enda tau nyelam.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: A person’s appearance doesn’t determine their ability.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Originates from traditional hunting culture comparing warriors and their weapons.
First Example Sentence: Enda semua orang berbadan besai pandai—laban jelu enda nyadi pemanah.
Second Example Sentence: Nya meh ti selalu dipesan orang tua, laban jelu enda nyadi pemanah.
Third Example Sentence: Aku arap iya, laban jelu enda nyadi pemanah, enda semua ke lembut ati lemah badan.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Verb phrase with object and locative complement
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To pursue something impossible or futile.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Rooted in agrarian imagery—seeking rice on stone implies futility.
First Example Sentence: Mun iya terus ngiga padi di batu, penusah iya aja nuan.
Second Example Sentence: Orang ke enda tau manding hal tu ngiga padi di batu.
Third Example Sentence: Ngiga padi di batu nya meh kerja orang enda ngira akal.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Suffering can bring strength or purification.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Pain can make a person stronger.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: References blacksmithing culture where friction polishes metal.
First Example Sentence: Air mata tebalu nyadi empelas, laban pengidup enda senang aja.
Second Example Sentence: Nadai guna nangis berlama, air mata tebalu nyadi empelas.
Third Example Sentence: Baka besi diasah, air mata tebalu nyadi empelas bagi ati.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To benefit indirectly from another’s effort.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Taking advantage of others’ hard work.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Relates to old cooking practices; scraping feathers at a shared hearth.
First Example Sentence: Bekikis bulu di tungku, iya aja ngambi nama orang.
Second Example Sentence: Orang ke pandai bekikis bulu di tungku selalu diingat tapi dibenci.
Third Example Sentence: Aku enda suka orang ke bekikis bulu di tungku, enda jujur iya.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Physical strength doesn’t mean endurance of spirit.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Being strong doesn’t mean being resilient.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Likely derived from blacksmithing and metaphors of metal strength.
First Example Sentence: Kati enda ngaga besi, laban ati lebih kuat ari tubuh.
Second Example Sentence: Orang tua selalu madah, kati enda ngaga besi.
Third Example Sentence: Mun kau ngelawan nasib, ingat kati enda ngaga besi.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Family ties remain strong despite conflict.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Derived from plant metaphors—branches may break but roots remain intact.
First Example Sentence: Kami selalu bepeda, tang puchok di urat enda putus.
Second Example Sentence: Enti pun begaduh, puchok di urat enda putus.
Third Example Sentence: Puchok di urat enda putus, kitai tetap sedarah.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: A free person speaks boldly without fear.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Refers to chickens that are not caged being more daring.
First Example Sentence: Manuk enda ngurung nyabak, baka orang bebas madah penemu iya.
Second Example Sentence: Mun nadai takut, manuk enda ngurung nyabak.
Third Example Sentence: Orang bebas baka manuk enda ngurung nyabak—berani, terus terang.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Parallel clause structure with metaphorical opposition
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Architectural metaphor from traditional longhouse building.
First Example Sentence: Enti tinggi pasak, dalam tiang, kitai tau teguh.
Second Example Sentence: Guru selalu madah, tinggi pasak, dalam tiang, baka pelajar rajin.
Third Example Sentence: Nya meh sebab pasal, tinggi pasak, dalam tiang, nadai mudah rebah.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Describes a marriage that seems perfect but is unreachable.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: An ideal that cannot be attained.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Derived from celestial imagery in Iban romantic folktales.
First Example Sentence: Bebini baka langit biru, indah di mata, jauh di tangan.
Second Example Sentence: Orang nya enda mudah, bebini baka langit biru aja.
Third Example Sentence: Enda semua impian nyadi nyata—bebini baka langit biru.
